description: The Iberian lynx is the largest feline in southern Europe and one of the most endangered on the planet. It is a species endemic to the Iberian Peninsula and originally distributed throughout it. Currently, its population is composed of 1,365 specimens, which has allowed it to go from being classified as 'critically endangered' to 'endangered'. Slender and long-legged, it is unmistakable by its beard and black brushes at the tips of its ears. The coat is brown with dark patches of varying size and density depending on the individual. The short tail is characteristic of all lynxes in the world.

The black rhino is a species of rhinoceros native to eastern and southern Africa. Despite its name, its skin is not actually black but gray. The species has suffered a dramatic population decline due to poaching and habitat loss. It is known for its hooked upper lip, which it uses to grasp leaves and twigs from shrubs and trees. Unlike the larger white rhino, the black rhino is more solitary and has a more aggressive temperament.

habitat: Coastal waters of the Indian and Pacific Oceans
description: The dugong is a large marine mammal that primarily feeds on seagrass. It is closely related to manatees and is the only living representative of the Dugongidae family. Dugongs are found in warm coastal waters from East Africa to Australia, including the Red Sea, Indian Ocean, and Pacific Ocean. They are slow-moving and rely on seagrass beds for sustenance, making them vulnerable to habitat destruction. Due to hunting, accidental entanglement in fishing gear, and habitat degradation, their populations have been declining.
